headline.main: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Damages From Cigarette Maker

docs.abstract: Jury in Oregon orders Philip Morris to pay more than $150 million in damages to estate of Michelle Schwarz, who died of lung cancer in 1999, finding that company falsely represented low-tar cigarettes as safer than regular ones; estate's attorneys held that Schwarz switched to Merit cigarettes for her health (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A Multnomah County jury ordered Philip Morris to pay more than $150 million in damages for falsely representing low-tar cigarettes as safer than regular ones. The jury found that by advertising low-tar cigarettes as less dangerous and failing to disclose research about the health effects of smoking, Philip Morris was in large part responsible for the death of Michelle Schwarz, 53, in 1999 from lung cancer. The suit was filed in state court by the estate of Mrs. Schwarz; estate lawyers said she switched to Merit cigarettes for her health. Matthew Preusch (NYT)
